pros: Fantastic job on cultivating a remarkable work culture and offering standard benefits, which have significantly contributed to fostering a growth-oriented mindset among the employees. Although it may take some time, your organization has demonstrated its commitment to continuous improvement, and the results are evident. During my rewarding 7-year tenure in the IT department, I had the pleasure of collaborating with the Salvation Army and its various units across Canada. The experience was nothing short of extraordinary, and I cherish the memories of working alongside dedicated and passionate individuals. One of the most commendable aspects of the organization is its emphasis on nurturing a positive work environment, where employees are encouraged to learn, develop, and innovate. This growth-oriented approach not only benefits the individual employees but also contributes to the organization's overall success. As with any organization, achieving a growth mindset takes time, and it's inspiring to witness how company has made consistent strides in this direction. This dedication to growth and improvement is a strong indicator of the organization's vision and values. In conclusion, I am immensely grateful for the opportunity to have been a part of such a forward-thinking and compassionate workplace. Working with the Salvation Army and its units across Canada has been a highlight of my career, and I look back on those years with fondness and pride.
cons: I dont really have anything to add here.

review_title: Wonderful Boss in Ricky Piedrahita and development team were all wonderful
job_title: Leadership Giving Officer in Toronto, ON
pros: -awesome professional development opportunities (through Harvard Manage Mentor & Veritus Group) -manageable workload -efficient processes administratively
cons: donor tracking spreadsheet was cumbersome and made for duplicated efforts in data entry (hours extra every week to keep this up to date when it could've just been pulled from the database)

pros: Supportive with training up. Consistent work. Great for financial stability. Great company who cultivates relationships with families.
cons: Too much coddling. Environment in all areas enjoys getting into your personal business. No boundaries - “we’re family” type of vibe. Hard to take time off without being shamed. Understaffed in all areas. Mental and emotional strain by verbally abusive staff. Nepotism. Not much positive excitement in day-to-day. Senior management were often times never on the same page. Very clicky.

job_title: Community Ministries Worker in Edmonton, AB
pros: Company culture is friendly and supportive, which you need when working in a stressful/busy environment. The salary is fairly low since it is a non-profit company but not bad. It was definitely a "living wage" in Edmonton. Full time and part time employees were offered enrolment in a benefits plan with GreenShield Canada, and they do RRSP matching up to I think 4%. Supervisors are usually kind and understanding especially when requesting flexibility due to family/personal issues.
cons: Busy environment, sometimes difficult not to take work mentally home with you (you meet a lot of people from all walks of life and often hear difficult stories). You certainly need a lot of compassion and good self-care to work a long time in the field. If you work in a church-based Salvation Army location, the culture/history is very strong and you need to have good boundaries not to get overworked.

pros: Contributing to making the community better
cons: Has extremely low salaries compared to current salaries in the province, whose job descriptions and duties are considerably less than mine. The starting salaries are higher than my salary, and I have been there for 15 years.

pros: it's a pretty easy job.
cons: passive-aggresive coworkers, management couldn't care less about you.

cons: Low pay Operational problems Lack of consideration of worker in terms of safety

review_title: Best colleagues anyone can ever meet
pros: Hafida and Danny's company will help you to grow and the people working there one day will be your second family.
cons: No cons for this small family

pros: Strong team, most people are empathetic and easy to work with Flexibility is available - work/life balance is encouraged [but not always possible] Occasional staff gatherings were enjoyable: Christmas luncheon, Staff Appreciation luncheon, celebrating birthdays etc.
cons: Low level compensation. Front-line workers pay was lower than the industry standard, however, management level and above was considerably higher. One or two members of staff made working conditions challenging for others - the complaints and concerns were submitted to management about these individuals essentially went unaddressed. Extremely hierarchical organisation which made any change or advancing toward more efficient processes almost impossible, especially if the suggestion was from the 'front-lines'. However, decisions to upgrade to a new system were made without consultation from front-line staff and the 'roll-out' was a disaster. The platform was not as useful as originally anticipated and caused more problems for 3 years. Gross lack of open communication from Headquarters and oftentimes the initial information would contain misinformation or lacking enough detail. They hire management staff primarily based upon status, and acquaintance level of the 'inner-circle' as opposed to hiring individuals on competency. They claim to use their resources responsibly, but I have witnessed several instances to the contrary.

pros: Staff are helpful and teamwork is visible
cons: Pay is lower compared to other hospitals in the area.

job_title: Residential Case Worker in Toronto, ON
pros: - Working with the same clients over a period of time, seeing them grow - Flexible schedule - Good experience for the resume
cons: So many. Terrible pay for the work we do, they barely pay enough to keep a roof over your head. Yet the Director of the program is on the Sunshine list! Because of low pay, there is high turnover and most of the staff are young, just out of college with minimal life experience. The quality of staff has completely tanked over the years, and I have noticed an impact on the clients. There are a couple good managers, but most do not care about the staff; they are burnt out, work from home as much as possible and don't communicate well with staff. Majority of managers have never worked anywhere else & aren't up to speed on best practices. Staff are given minimal supervision, guidance or oversight. We have implemented new programs and practices without much forethought and these are not doing well.

review_title: Hands down my favorite job I've ever had.
job_title: Retail Sales Associate in Medicine Hat, AB
pros: I thoroughly enjoyed going into work every day at the Salvation Army in Medicine Hat, AB. I would definitely still be there if I hadn't moved and would love any opportunity I get to work at another one in the future. The hours were amazing and the pay was just above minimum just like any other retail store job. Set schedule 9-5, every Thursday and Sunday off (they're closed Sunday). Positive prayer every morning to start off the day. There were 3 floors to the store; housewares, clothing, and furniture. I mostly worked on the main floor with the clothing and absolutely loved it. Constantly something to do between working the cash register, cleaning change rooms, assisting customers, dressing mannequins so the day went by super fast. Sometimes I helped upstairs where they accepted the donations, sorted through clothes and made the clothing racks so there was quite the variety of jobs to do. The best part was being apart of a nonprofit organization who help so many people that are struggling in our communities. I would recommend anyone work there if they are given the opportunity!
cons: In order to do this job you have to be okay with working in a dusty and at times a dirty environment. You also have to be comfortable dealing with customers who are at times unstable who come into the store and be accepting of there situation and know how to handle it. All in all for anyone who loves people and takes pride in helping them this is a great job for you!

job_title: Special Care Attendant (Level II Special Care Home) in Saint John, NB
pros: We are a level 2 special care home. Most all employees like their job because of our clients. We want to be there for them. We are unionized. We have a collective agreement between our local and the Center of Hope. Good medical plan, RRSP, etc..
cons: Our employer came to us with big ideas and everyone agreed to help turn the center around and make it a good place to work for everyone. That did not last long. Threats from management that the center would be closed if we did not agree to their wishes, its our way or the highway attitude towards staff, and finally the many agreements they have broke between the union and the Salvation Army.

review_title: Do Not Work Here Unless You Are Desperate For a Job
job_title: Part-time Store Associate in Toronto, ON
pros: You are constantly pushed for efficiency. You will learn how to work fast in a clever way on your own. Employees are friendly.
cons: High turnover rate, definitely not a place for promotion. Supervisor is rude and disrespectful to employees. Exploiting employees and blaming employees for not doing their tasks well while the store is constantly running out of staff. Supervisor would "automatically" deduct your hourly wage when your are minutes late, but never counts the minutes in when you stay and work longer than usual unless you speak up. Training is okay, but you are always given one task throughout the day. Learning new skills is "prohibited" unless you are trusted by your supervisor and have worked long enough.  If you are in your prime (16s, 20s), you are likely to bear all the real chores and heavy duties. Billions of donation or "garbage" are waiting for you to sort, price-tagging and place them on the floor. No doubt, you will be drained after each shift. Exhausted? Get hurt during work? Your manager would turn a blind eye/deaf ear to that. This is not a Christian charity, but a commercial firm skilled at taking advantage of its employees.

review_title: Its the worst organization that I have worked in, I feel so sorry for the people that work their in production,
pros: I would never ever donate to this organization again, their all in it for the money, they don't care about their employees, i will donate to shelters & battered women with children, I am insulted that I ever worked in a place like that
cons: It's a race all day to get your numbers, 960 pieces of clothing a day in NB. I would not recommend anyone to work their, we have worn our winter coats in the building because he would not turn up the heat, we ran out of toilet paper, sharing the same needles for the pricing machine, and not making out a report when I had fallen over a rack, did this in the month of January and February when the we had very cold weather

pros: People care about fellow coworkers, generous time off, flexible if asked.  The benefits are good: tuition reimbursment, sick days can be carried over, etc. Management will genuinely help with work/life balance and have a good open door policy should you have a concern.  Opportunity for travel occassionally is another perk.
cons: A bit too much Management. But over all, great people, can't complain.  There were not enough promotion openings, but some people were able to make some good financial jumps when they moved up that they may not have necessarily been hired for had they not worked a lower level job there.

pros: The benefits are great until you realize what kind of company you are working for. If you love companies whose major component is there ridiculous Human Resources department whose number one priority is protecting the companies image this place is for you!!
cons: This is not a charity organization this is a power/money hungry business. Every year they intentionally give every employee a raise a week or so BEFORE the provinces government has their minimum wage raised so when that raise happens it exceeds the raise given by the company. Employees who have been there for years therefore never earn above minimum wage, showing just how much they value them.

pros: The only pro is the positive reaction you receive from the service users after you do a great job of supporting them.
cons:
The work is stressful and the pay is not enough to cover for monthly expenses in a city such as Toronto.
Do not ask for a wage increase because they would give you 36 cents per year; this is a slap in your face for the great work you do but cant afford to buy food.

Good luck trying to move up the ladder (98% of the time, you need to be White to move up as a Counsellor). The organization, management and HR are all racist but do not admit it

review_title:
Meh- don't waste your time if you like office jobs. 
Store Associate -_-
pros: Giving back to the community and being able to help others In a way that they have the most gratitude.  The 50% off merchandise even though I never used it.
cons:
Long hours 
Standing for hours
Messy store 
Dust from clothes- I was sneezing all the time while working there 
Management was the worst.  Wasn't understanding in circumstances. 
Some co workers had a power trip. 
Not enough pay for the responsibilities.  
Pushing carts back and forth across store can be tiring. 
Not very glamorous job. 
If you like office jobs don't waste your time here !

review_title: Working at the Salvation Army Thrift Store
pros: Compensation was higher than other part time jobs. The staff was really nice and always helpful. To stay on the good side of all of the staff you have to work hard. Great deals all the time even if you're not an employee. Also very flexible and understanding team.
cons: Can be very busy and hard to keep up at certain times. Volunteers are not always placed correctly. Hard to always have a full staff team at every hour.

review_title: Assisting fellow citizens maintain their dignity and uplift their social statuses.
job_title: Front Desk Attendant in Thunder Bay, ON
pros:
I enjoy giving people a hand up versus a hand-out. We assist people through difficult times and 
welcome their contributing back in any way to help assist others in distress. As their experience relays well to be shared to ease the stress and pain of their immediate misfortune.
cons: Only being able to offer so much. We cannot live peoples lives for them, we can only offer them the tools required to decide which action they themselves desire. We offer guidance and support, but leave the people the power to decide their solutions for their individual circumstances!

pros:
There were some great staff who worked there, and the clients were interesting, and challenging at the same time. It was a really flexible job-something you could always fall back on.
Some of the managers were terrific-supportive, and willing to listen to feedback.
cons: Some staff were lazy, and ignored the clients. Some staff felt entitled to use their cellphones all day long for talking, texting and surfing.

pros: Learn to work effectively with limited budget, lots of skill training and development
cons: Like most Non-profits it has a lower salary then other similar private sector jobs

review_title: Great job, but physically and mentally demanding.
pros:
Great co-workers: obviously this would vary from store to store, but my co-workers and especially my manager are amazing. You really feel like you matter, and I feel safe enough to cone forward with any concerns I have.
Good hours: I receive many more hours than promised when I took the job. I started out part-time, expecting 20 hours a week, but received 25-35 hours on average (could be a con I guess depending on who you are). My manager was understanding of transportation issues I have and allowed me to start/leave 30 minutes before most employees. I will be starting full-time soon. 
Holiday pay: everybody gets paid holidays, even me being part-time.
Birthday gift: everybody gets a $20 gift card for their birthday from the company :)
Benefits: I haven't started full-time yet, so I haven't received them, but who doesn't like benefits and paid sick days?
Lots of breaks: you get two paid 15-minute breaks every 8-hour shift, plus an unpaid 30 minute lunch break, but you're scheduled for 8.5 hours so you still get 8 hours of pay each day. On 4-5.5 hour shifts you get one 15-minute break.
Variety: some days I work out back in the production room, sorting through donations, hanging them, or pricing them. And some days I work out front either at the cash/cleaning up/ putting things away, or just cleaning up/putting things away. It's nice to have a bit of variety, not always doing the same thing. I also work Sundays currently, and I do something different every sunday: cleaning, organizing, mopping, sweeping, etc
Discount: if you thought thrift stores were already great, you'll love the 50% (25% off matresses/pillows) off discount on top of the already amazing prices.
Doing good: just the thought of doing good in your community is great, not many other retail employees can boast that. Being able to help needy people that come into the store is a great feeling.
cons:
Physically demanding: whether you work out back or on the floor prepare to be sore after work, and but comfy shoes! I still get sore and have been here for 6-7 months. Working out back will get you a sore back, arms, and sometimes lower legs, from lifting, testing open, hanging, etc. Working on the floor will earn you sore feet and legs from running around like a chicken with it's head cut off. I've work a step counter to work on the floor before and done 13000 steps in a 4.5 hour shift. (For comparison 6000 in an entire day is considered an active lifestyle.)
Mentally exhausting: as with most retail jobs, the constant mess, clean up, rowdy kids, and less-thsn-kind customers can make you want to cry when you finally lock the doors at the end of the night.
Morale problems: it's easy to lose morale when your customers are being ungrateful, when there's a spike in stealing, when every donation bag you open is wet, musty, mothball-smelling, dirty underwear, dirty socks, old, stained, just plain nasty, etc.
Poor training: I was not trained sufficiently when I was hired. I was basically thrown on cash after only learning how to type in the price of items/scan them (there's a while lot of other buttons on there) and wasn't taught much about any slips or sheets we had to fill out for certain purchases/events. It was more of a "learn from your mistakes" training.
Feels like you're at work all the time. Sometimes I work night, and then the following morning. Feels like I never left. You never know what your schedule is until a few days before usually.

job_title: Shelter Worker I in Vancouver, BC
pros: Harbour light provides a reasonable compensation and benefits package. It's hardly impressive but it will keep your bills paid and lights on, with 3 weeks vacation and RRSP contributions, it's not too shabby. It's a BCGEU union shop, which does provide some job security. For do-gooder types, it's a decent employer, giving you an opportunity to work full time helping society's most vulnerable individuals and give you the sense you're helping to make the world a better place. I personally found my direct manager to be reasonable, flexible and helpful.
cons: Harbour Light has a management problem. Light corruption is endemic. Nepotism (hiring of personal friends with no qualifications into high paying positions) does occur from time to time, although efforts have been made to curb that by head office. The union local is completely owned by management. Two of the shop stewards are managers, and somehow the union hall is allowing this. Your co-workers in front-line positions are often recruited from former clients, and while many are conscientious, helpful people, a large number are mentally unstable, uneducated, and often make problems worse in dealing with clients and can create more violent incidents than if you had just been working alone. Staff safety is not a priority for management, and violence in the workplace is extremely common, if anything management policies actually lead to greater risk. Poor coordination between casework and front line staff, poor coordination between management and front line staff. Management can be extremely arrogant and have on many occasions shown outright contempt for front line staff.

review_title: Decent for union employees, nothing for managers
pros: Being able to support a disadvantaged population and obtaining really meaningful employment experience.
cons: As a manager, you are expected to be on-call 24/7 with no relief. The programs there continue to grow, but your salary will remain stagnant and you will continually be expected to do more with little recognition financially and with very little support.

review_title: Good for gaining entry level experience
pros:
provide great services to the community
my immediate manager has been great to work with and is open to feedback and implementing positive workplace changes
wages are good in relation to similar jobs in this region
cons:
the overall company is hesitant to implement changes
high staff turnover/overtime often requested of employees
this is a religious organization and thus if you are not a christian some practices (i.e. trainings held in the church, prayer at christmas parties/dinners etc.) may feel uncomfortable--but notable that it is not required for employees to follow a christian faith

pros: 50% if you buy its the only positive thing
cons: for $12 at least we should  be treated like humans. But it doesn't seem they are good Samaritans or good  Christians, they are using this charity label to take advantage of the people who donate, the people who work and the clients.. And it's working, its a good business but not a good christian charity. Unfortunately no respect for the employees, psychological harassment, they try to take money from your salary if you don't check regularly.. Bad environment place to work, I don't advice anyone to work there,

pros:

poor pay
